course_title: Chinese to English Translation: An Introductory Course

learning_outcomes.description: translate/revise common genres from Chinese into idiomatic English in a linguistically and culturally appropriate manner
access and understand the application of a variety of translation resources and conduct translation revision
have a basic grasp of Hanyu Pinyin
understand traditional and simplified character Chinese texts
have a basic linguistic vocabulary to talk about texts

assessments.task_description:
Type: E-quizzes on Blackboard

Reading: 0 minutes

Duration: 20 minutes

Format: Translation and multiple-choice

Starting from Week 2, each Monday, an online quiz will be posted on the "Assessment" page on Blackboard, which you must complete before Friday 5 pm of the same week. 

On three "odd" [单数] week (Weeks 7, 9 & 11), the online quiz is a practical translation revision task (consisting of 4-8 sentences) based on the contents of the preceding week(s) and/or that week.

On an "even" [双数] week (Weeks 2, 4, 6, 8, 10 &12 ), the online quiz is a multiple choice quiz (consisting of 8 questions) that tests what is discussed in that week's and the preceding week's Online Modules. There is only 1 correct answer for each of the 8 questions.

The best 8 e-quiz results for each student will be used to calculate the final mark for this assessment item.

You must complete an e-quiz in 20 minutes without interruption. So, be sure to use reliable internet, e.g. UQL.

No reading time is allowed. 

AI and MT Statement

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance. A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.

assessments.task_description:
The in-semester assessment will test students' knowledge and understanding of all the W1-W5 course content, particularly the in-class materials. Students will translate seen texts or texts similar to the in-class materials (25% of exam content) and an unseen text (75% of exam content), based on Newspaper Texts 1 & 2, and Film Texts 1 & 2. The unseen text is approximately 320 characters in length. The texts will represent the different genres studied in W1-W5 (i.e. sign, news, film). Students may have access to lecture notes and paper dictionaries during the exam. 

The exam is online on Blackboard. Be sure to access a reliable internet connection. It is strongly recommended you save your work on a Word file as well.

You will have 60 minutes of working time plus 10 minutes for planning. Your time begins once you start the exam, and it must be completed in a single sitting.

 You may use any printed materials or online tools to complete this assessment, but getting help from other people is strictly prohibited.

AI and MT Statement

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance. A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.

Each student will be assigned a time slot in Exam WEEK 1 Monday or Tuesday. If students have time clashes with other exams, please reach out to your class teacher for a rearrangement.
assessments.task_description:
The final oral is an in-person sight translation task. It will test students' knowledge and understanding and application of the course content, particularly the in-class materials. Students will be required to sight translate one Chinese text into spoken English. Each document is around 300 characters long and will be handed out at the assessment venue. E-dictionaries that work offline will be provided. Students will have 10 minutes to prepare for sight translating each document and need to finish the task within the time limit of 7 minutes.

AI and MT Statement

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
